Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2016 08:11PM Bellefleur wrote: it's more than likely from nursing. If your concerned then definitely see a doctor because they are the only ones that can say for sure. But mine is from nursing. I had ultrasound, mammogram and MRI to make sure and I saw a breast specialist. He explained it as sensitive estrogen receptors that have made ligaments lazy so they aren't doing their job to keep the breast the same contour. It is also only in my one breast. Hope that helps
Posts.Title: Breast contour change/ dimple Sdigiulio Bellefleur

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2016 03:53PM Bellefleur wrote: I have a similar issue my left breast has what my dr described as tethering and an indentation. Nothing showed up on my mammo or US I just had an MRI but haven't gotten my results from it. I see a breast specialist on the 29th. If you'd like I'll keep you posted about what happens with my appointment. I've had two kids and breast fed them both my GP thinks it might be from that but with a family history of three of my great aunts having breast or ovarian cancer they don't want to chance it. Sorry you are going through this while pregnant. I'd wait till the baby is born so that you can get the best results from testing and keep that sweet thing safe
Posts.Title: I just don't know what i should do! Long... Ali81

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2016 06:13PM Bellefleur wrote: mkinoly did your bc show up in ultrasound or mammogram? Both came back clear for me so I had an MRI and am waiting on the results from that. Also did you have a palpable lump or and pain? I have pain and fullness in my breast and armpit but no lumps. Thank
Posts.Title: Breast flattening and indented. Anyone?? Ali81

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2016 10:54PM Bellefleur wrote: ibc is one of if not the rarest of breast cancers. It's definitely good to get it checked out but they chances are so small so I hope you take solice in that. Majority of the time if you are pregnant and get these symptoms it is because of the weird chances our bodies go through during pregnancy. Many will go away in a few days or weeks other the only thing that will fix it is having the baby. I hope this help ease your anxiety. And congratulations on your pregnancy. focus on the joy of that to keep your mind off of what your breasts are doing
Posts.Title: Pregnant with IBC Symptoms HeatherJS HeatherJS

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2016 09:05AM Bellefleur wrote: it can be common for women to have nipple retraction during pregnancy and while breastfeeding. Pregnancy really can do a number on our breasts. many women get mastitis as well as fungal or yeast infections on their breasts. I'd say almost all the pregnant women that have come on here worried about IBC have had it come back as B9 and one of those three things. All breast issue should be checked by dr. And if you are a worry wart like me seeing a specialist is really the only way to feel at ease.
Posts.Title: Pregnant with IBC Symptoms HeatherJS HeatherJS

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2016 10:24AM Bellefleur wrote: that it's exactly what happened when I went in for a breast ultrasound and they said the radiology wanted a mammogram. Then said looks good you can go home your doctor will get the report in so many days. Everything was fine I have B9 breast issues so no cancer. So take a deep breath it's very possible the spot you saw was a cyst and the radiologist because of your family history just wanted to get a baseline for future mammograms as you get older. I felt super scared when they did that to me. I felt like what aren't you telling me. I feel it's all good the next why more images?? I think they just don't realize the stress and anxiety we are going through so don't communicate effectively. Hope you get the call soon and that everything is B9
Posts.Title: Time frame to diagnosis, worried. strength80 kjam

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2016 09:44AM Bellefleur wrote: I feel for you I have that let down feeling and indentations in my left breast. It's a nauseating feeling having to worry about it. I have also have had auterine oblation and had emergency gullbladder surgery. I've also had my appendix out and 3 operations on my ankle. So trust me when I say that the gullbladder surgery isn't fun But is a fairly quick recovery just take it easy. It's hard when you feel like you've drawn the genetic short straw but I just remember you only get what you can handle therefore you must be stronger than you realize

Posts.Content: Feb 29, 2016 07:47PM Bellefleur wrote: I have the same problem my doctor isn't bothering with a mammogram since they are less than reliable for woman with dense breast tissue. I'm going for an ultrasound tomorrow is the second best shot a seeing something if it is there. The best so far that I've read is a MRI but they can take a while to get. At least here they are. Good luck I hope everything works out for you
